content: after hours of traversing this dense forest it finally gives way to a small
clearing at the center stands a single solemn statue suddenly without warning
the sound of horses pounding earth disturbs the silence as dark figures on
horseback bows drawn erupted from within the trees you take position as best you
can ready to fight to the death if required
these trees provide some much-needed cover as you attempt to gain at least a
shred of advantage while caught so completely off-guard
hey guys welcome back to black magic crap last week I took some cheap holiday
Christmas village pine trees and I flocked them and made them look a whole
heck of a lot better but then I have to put them back on some basis so that's
what I'm doing in this episode and I chose not to put them back on their
individual plastic cheap crappy basis but instead I chose to group them on
larger bases so they'd be a little bit easier to move around and play with and
faster to place on the table this also meant that I was able to make those
bases a lot more scenic looking and interesting I decided to not cheap out
here or take the easy or lazy route and I did the right thing and put them on
MDF bases which is a fair bit of extra prep work but totally worth it in the
end I think they turned out pretty awesome I'm happy with the bill so let's
take a look at how I did it I wasn't messing around here I knew I wanted
these to be on MDF bases so I grabbed some off cuts left over from my snow
terrain boards and set to work drawing out my base shapes I used the
original plastic tree bases that I had saved as a reference this way I could
know how many trees I was working with and how many of each size I wasn't
worried about sticking to these layouts perfectly as the bill progressed but
doing this ensured that I ended up with the right number of bases appropriate to
the number of trees I had even if they ended up switching spots later with my
rough shapes drawn out it was time to cut them now this could be done with a
jigsaw but it is far less awkward to do so with a scroll saw if you have one I
didn't follow my shape super closely as they were just a rough guide
I then needed to bevel all the edges and
for this I used a small orbital hand sander and this was not the ideal tool
for this I was very much wishing that I had a benchtop disc or belt sander
instead but hey it got the job done even if it was a very messy job I wanted to
break up the flatness of the bases with some big rocks so I grabbed some XPS
insulation foam and carved some rock formations using just an Olfa knife this
is easily done by cutting a general shape and then scoring a bunch of lines
that cross each other after which you can use the edge of the blade to scrape
away the material this creates a nice jagged and non uniform texture
after hot gluing the foam to the bases I cut in some flat areas on the stones by
making a horizontal cut and a vertical cut and then breaking away the material
this creates some nice little plateaus in the stone
I had just recently tested and reviewed
the Vallejo ground cover pace and I thought this would be a perfect project
to actually use them on I decided to use the gray pumice as it seemed to be the
coarsest of all the textures I first brushed on some water onto the MDF now
this is a really important step when adhering things to MDF especially if the
adhesive isn't very liquidy the water soaks into the material and helps the
adhesive soak deeper rather than just drying on the surface
after applying the paste I placed some
larger gravel at the basis of the foam rocks to help ease the transition from
ground to large stone on some of the bases I applied the pace fairly heavily
and on some of them I put it on thinner to see if I could get away with using
less of the material as I'm sitting here looking at these watching them dry I'm
realizing that well I do like the way this texture paste looks where it is
thicker but where I tried to be more sparing and just put a thin layer I'm
not overly thrilled it looks great if I wanted it to look
like sand but I'm thinking I want these to look more like like a muddy earth a
pile of you know kind of dirt beneath the tree and this is just a little too
thin so I think I'm gonna scrap this it was a valiant effort wanted to test the
material in real practice but I think I'm gonna switch gears and mix up some
caulking and thin it or something and spread that over top to give a more
muddy thick texture to these so I turned to plan B and decided to make my own
ground paste I wanted something that was really thick and full of a variety of
textures I started with white acrylic culkin now the caulking on its own is
far too thick to work with so I diluted it with some water then I added in some
sand that had a mix of fine and medium aggregate to add a bit more earthy
texture I added in some tea grounds now this is just the inside of unused
teabags these dried herbs are great for simulating forest debris like twigs and
leaves a mixed into mud I also added in a fair amount of black paint to the mix
so that it would be easier to paint later
at the last minute I remembered my
pencil sharpener and decided to mix in a bunch of pencil shavings I thought this
might give it even more of an organic debris look but it is the one item I
regretted adding later the shavings from my particular sharpener are long strands
and they are curly and they ended up sticking out and looking kind of weird
and big and out of place as the project progressed so I would probably leave
those out next time before applying my homemade paste to the bases I covered
the foam rocks in my Blackmagic craft base coat which is just the mix of Mod
Podge and black paint then to apply the paste I just used a large craft paint
brush and spread it on I was actually really happy with how easily and well it
applied and spread
I was far happier with the heavier and more dynamic texture of the homemade
paste but the real downside was how long it took to dry the Vallejo paste dried
in like twenty to thirty minutes which is incredible my homemade paste took
hours and hours and hours I actually ended up having to leave them overnight
by a heater before I could move on to painting them once they were dry though
I was really happy with the results especially how hard they became the
texture was really well bonded and all of the aggregate was really locked in
before painting them I cleaned up any excess texture that got on the underside
of the bases so that they would sit nice and flat on the table it was then time
to paint and I started by first painting out the large rocks just for fun I
decided to use the opportunity to practice a bit more with my new airbrush
this absolutely wasn't necessary but I wanted to test something with it with my
first cheap airbrush I had a lot of problems it got clogged all the time you
put water in it and it clogged since getting my iwata one I've been having a
lot more success very little problems with clogging so I wanted to test it
with craft paint which is notoriously thick and chunky with large pigments and
I wanted to see if I could get away with it if the new airbrush could handle it
so I watered down some craft paint and to my pleasant surprise it did seem to
work not nearly as well as it worked with model paint but it did get the job
done
for the ground cover I painted out a coating of very watered-down brown on
the rest of the basis this I decided to do the old-fashioned way with a brush as
I thought it would be easier to control and honestly I didn't feel like cleaning
out the airbrush again to highlight the textures on the ground cover I did some
dry brushing using a golden brown some tan and even a bit of olive green I also
let some of this get on the stones to give them a little bit more color
it was the washes that really made these begin to look good however I used my
homemade washes that I made in a previous episode for the rocks
I used my black wash and for the ground texture I used a brown wash
once the washers were dry I could move
on to the long-awaited step of attaching the trees using a rotary tool and very
small drill bits to match the size of the wire on the trees I drilled in some
holes right into the MDF then it was a simple matter of putting some PVA glue
on the wire and placing the trees in their holes the most important thing
here is to not drill a hole that is too big or the tree will just want to fall
over before the glue dries oh and it's also important to put some material
underneath the base so that if you drill all the way through you don't end up
with holes in your cutting mat self-healing cutting mat don't heal
holes
the last bit of detail I decided to add was a variety of static grass Tufts just
to break up the bases a little bit more I considered adding some flocking but I
really liked the look of the brown bases against the trees there was a nice
juxtaposition and contrast of color there and I wanted to avoid them looking
too similar overall I'm really happy with how these look they are the right
balance of realistic versus durable and playable I'm not going to be too worried
about them getting damaged but they still look believable if you
want to pick up any tools or supplies for this build head over to Blackmagic
craft CA where I have my essential equipment store with links to all of the
things I use and recommend you can also check the video description below for
links to items specific to this build that might not be up on the website
purchasing through those affiliate links helps fund these videos another way you
can help fund future videos the best way in fact is by supporting Blackmagic
crafts on patreon the support from viewers there is the reason this channel
continues to exist and grow and what allow me to dedicate my full efforts
into these videos and this community I'd love to have you as the newest member of
the black magic crafts fellowship there you have it guys some really cheap
holiday Christmas trees now completely transformed and placed on much better
basis this is a great option as it still keeps these trees really affordable if
you're willing to put in the extra work but I think it's worth it hope you guys
found this video informative entertaining and most of all inspiring
if you did hit that like button and let me know in the comments section below I
will see you guys again next week Cheers happy crafting
